fields.quote: What tools are you using for transcription and analysis?
As you know, we're developing Raijin.ai, an application that uses AI to extract important points from transcripts.
Can you describe an example from your work where understanding context and nuance was crucial?
How do you see Raijin.ai fitting into or enhancing this collaborative aspect?
The idea of using AI to automatically extract important points from transcripts sounds like it could save us a lot of time and effort.
Claudia: It can vary depending on the length of the interview and the depth of insights we’re looking for, but on average, I’d say each transcript can take anywhere from 3 to 6 hours to process.
I’m curious to know how Raijin.ai handles these subtleties.
Caleb: Would an automated tagging system within Raijin.ai help with this?
Caleb: On a related note, how important is the user interface and experience of Raijin.ai for you and your team?
I’d say we usually have to spend about 15-30 minutes per transcript just cleaning up errors and making sure everything is correct.
If you had to name the top three outcomes or benefits you’d like to see from using Raijin.ai, what would they be?
Claudia: My main concern is whether the AI can truly understand the nuances of human conversation.
Claudia: It would be great if the AI could not only extract key points but also categorize them.
Claudia: A comprehensive but straightforward onboarding process would be ideal.
We record these sessions, transcribe them, and then manually go through the transcripts to highlight key insights.
What would you say are the biggest challenges you face with this manual process?
For transcription, we rely on services like Rev or Otter.ai.
We’re planning to include a robust onboarding process and ongoing support.
Claudia: It can vary depending on the length of the interview and the depth of insights we’re looking for, but on average, I’d say each transcript can take anywhere from 3 to 6 hours to process.
The transcription tools don’t integrate directly with our analysis documents, so there’s a lot of copy-pasting involved, which adds to the time and potential for errors.

Claudia: We manually tag sections of the transcript with different categories like pain points, positive feedback, suggestions, etc.
What are some of the biggest challenges you face when analyzing transcripts manually?
Jim:  Another challenge is ensuring consistency across researchers.
So, as you mentioned, Raijin.ai utilizes AI and natural language processing (NLP) to analyze transcripts.
With multiple interviews, it can be challenging to keep track of everything and identify recurring themes across the data set.
Even with a coding system, different researchers might highlight different points based on their interpretations.
Does the volume of text ever make it difficult to identify important trends or patterns?
Understanding Raijin.ai and Potential Benefits
An application that could automatically summarize key points and identify patterns across transcripts would be incredibly valuable.
It sounds like Raijin.ai could potentially address some of these pain points by automating the initial analysis and highlighting key themes.
Raijin.ai can automatically categorize these elements based on pre-defined criteria or user personas you establish.
Caleb:  Finally, Raijin.ai is being developed to visualize connections across transcripts.
Analyzing transcripts can be very time-consuming, especially with large datasets.
Raijin.ai can analyze how users feel throughout the interview, whether they're frustrated, excited, or confused.
